content.text: Stage 1: Collection

Data collection is composed of its own set of sub-activities that support the extraction and transmission of raw data to a dedicated server or cloud platform. This process starts by first outlining the overarching objectives that necessitate data collection, and these objectives will enable the identification of relevant software necessary for achieving the set objectives. For example, a government can outline objectives related the decarbonization and modernization of energy systems through the adoption of smart grids, as is seen with the government of Mauritius The data collection process, outlining key activities to consider for the data source identification, data capturing technologies, and communication requirements for transmission.

concepts.title: data lifecycle
concepts.body: The data lifecycle refers to the stages that data goes through from its initial creation and storage, through its use and sharing, to its eventual archiving or deletion.

concepts.title: data value chain
concepts.body: The data value chain refers to the series of steps involved in collecting, processing, analyzing, and utilizing data to create value and inform decision-making.

concepts.title: equitable data access
concepts.body: Equitable data access refers to the fair and just availability of data to all individuals and communities, ensuring that everyone has the opportunity to access, use, and benefit from data resources, regardless of their socioeconomic status, location, or other barriers.

content.text: Lesson 3 Overview

The transition toward renewable energy sources and technologies for Sustainable Energy Development (SED) has become a global priority, driven by the need to address critical challenges such as poverty alleviation, environmental protection, socioeconomic growth, and the modernization of energy systems. Central to achieving these goals is the imperative to ensure affordable and inclusive energy access for all. Within this landscape, data have emerged as indispensable assets, enabling real-time, evidence-based decision making, informing energy strategies, guiding end-user actions, and fostering innovation to accelerate sustainable energy development.

The concept of the data value chain provides a framework for understanding how raw data are transformed into actionable insights that enhance decision making. This chain encompasses the entire process, from the initial generation of data through sensor devices to its collection, transformation, analysis, and eventual utilization. Each stage of the chain is crucial in ensuring that data-driven insights effectively support energy system optimization, decentralized energy solutions, grid management, and demand-side efficiency improvements.

Effective data management and processing underpin the success of the data value chain, enabling its application in a variety of energy system interventions. These include optimizing energy generation and storage, alleviating grid constraints, and supporting the development of decentralized energy assets. For example, the Rwanda Distributed Generation Initiative employs real-time sensor-based monitoring for improved data collection, while the Energy4Sahel Program utilizes geospatial data for rural electrification strategy and planning. Similarly, the Africa Mini-grid Program focuses on impact monitoring and evaluation to inform policies, develop business models, and create innovative financing mechanisms. These initiatives demonstrate how data can drive evidence-based decisions, inform regulatory reforms, and support the widespread adoption of Sustainable Energy Systems (SESs). This lesson delves deeper into the stages of the data value chain and explore the challenges faced by developing communities in leveraging data for sustainable energy development. This analysis highlights the critical role of data in bridging knowledge gaps and advancing equitable energy transitions.

content.title: Part 1: Stages of the Data Value Chain

content.text: Part 1 Overview

The data value chain is composed of four core interlinked stages: collection, transformation, value creation, and utilization of data. These core stages are embedded with data management sub- activities, that collectively ensure the quality and integrity of the data delivered from the data source to the end user for utilization. The nest figure illustrates how data flow through each of the four stages until they are converted into insights that support data-driven decision-making.
Data Generation and Collection

Once the application and corresponding data generation sources have been identified, data capturing technologies are strategically deployed on the location of interest to extract raw data that will be used to inform strategies and support evidence-based decision making. Typical deployment areas include renewable energy systems providing data on generation levels and system operation, weather stations providing data on weather conditions, and metering devices with energy consumption insights. The deployed technology extracts and records the raw data, preparing it for transmission through the communication network to the analytics platform.

Energy data generation and collection are fundamental to the functionality and progression of smart grids. The following graphic shows the evolution from conventional grids to Smart Grid 1.0 and Smart Grid 2.0, highlighting how data has become central to building more dynamic and interconnected energy systems. Components such as smart meters, microgrids, and distribution network management rely on continuous data flows to support monitoring, analysis, and optimization. These data streams, gathered from diverse sources like renewable energy systems, electric vehicles, and peer-to-peer energy trading platforms, enable more accurate energy planning and decision-making. As data becomes embedded in every aspect of the energy system, smart grids are not only improving operational performance but are also creating the foundation for tackling systemic challenges, including grid reliability, equitable resource allocation, and the transition to low-carbon energy.
Data Transmission

The transmission phase incorporates data transmission from the acquisition device, through the communication network, and to a dedicated server or cloud platform for processing. The data capturing technology is typically embedded with a communication module that facilitates data transfer from the device to a gateway that then transmits the data to a cloud platform for processing. For edge devices, data acquisition collection is paired with storage and processing at the source location, and the data are transmitted through the network for analysis without undergoing additional processing. The data are transmitted over wireless technologies, such as cellular networks, LPWAN (Low Power Wide Area Network), Satellite communications, and WI-FI, and the selection of the transmission technology depends on the size of the data packets being transmitted.
Stage 2: Transformation

This phase involves the conversion of data into usable format for analysis. This process ensures the packet delivered to the analytics platform has the correct format and is compatible with the central application platform, which is especially important in systems with multiple sources using peculiar datasets. There are two subprocesses encapsulated under this pillar: data processing and data storage (Tawakuli & Engel, 2022).
Data Processing

This is a critical step that initiates value extraction from the obtained datasets. It is a process that transforms the raw data into a usable format that can be interpreted by the analytics platform by cleaning the data and fixing missing and invalid values, and duplicate observations. When done properly, this step enhances the integrity of the data. Because of the volume, velocity, and variety of data , it is critical to use tools and techniques like the Data Governance Framework , data quality assurance tools like the IBM Databand and Bboxx , and data standardization practices to produce consistency within heterogenous datasets using resources such as the Energy Sector Management Assistance Program (ESMAP).
Data Storage

Data from multiple sources are aggregated and stored , to be pulled at a later stage for processing. Data are stored locally at the site location, which mitigates network inconsistencies that may affect real-time transmission for remote applications, and, after transmission, also in remote cloud-based storage platforms. Data can then be pulled from the database and analyzed.
Data Value Chain tools, technologies, and mechanisms that support data transformation to actionable insights
Stage 3: Value Creation/Addition

The Value Creation stage is the cornerstone for translating raw data into actionable insights, enabling informed and strategic decision-making. At this stage, processed data from diverse sources undergo thorough analysis to uncover patterns, predict trends, and identify anomalies. These insights serve as the bedrock for optimizing energy systems and enhancing operational efficiencies. Advanced data analysis tools enable everything from real-time monitoring to long-term forecasting, laying the groundwork for evidence-based interventions. Initiatives such as the Data Futures Exchange exemplify how data-driven insights can be transformed into platforms that inspire tangible actions and systemic improvements.
Data Analytics

Data analytics within the value creation process is multifaceted, encompassing various categories tailored to different objectives. Each category contributes uniquely to building a comprehensive understanding of energy systems, driving solutions, and enabling resilience in the face of challenges. Descriptive Analytics Descriptive analytics focuses on interpreting historical data to provide a clear understanding of past trends, patterns, and relationships. This category builds frameworks that help end-users make sense of their data, fostering better decision making. In the context of sustainable energy: Energy consumption data reveals historical usage trends, informing strategies for efficiency and sustainability. Power generation data from diverse energy sources helps identify typical patterns, facilitating supply-demand matching and strategic grid expansion.

Predictive Analytics Predictive analytics leverages statistical models, econometric techniques, and machine learning algorithms to anticipate future trends and scenarios. These insights empower stakeholders to address challenges proactively: Sectoral energy demand forecasts incorporate indicators like GDP, population growth, and industrial activity to ensure effective resource allocation and policy design. Weather data analysis predicts renewable energy plant performance, enabling optimal site selection and system design for solar and wind energy projects. Equipment monitoring systems use inverter alerts and sensor data to detect anomalies, allowing pre-emptive maintenance and reducing system downtime.

Prescriptive Analytics Prescriptive analytics advances beyond prediction, offering actionable recommendations for optimizing energy systems. AI-driven models and Decision Support Systems (DSS) play a pivotal role in this category: Smart meter data drives incentive-based strategies like demand response programs, encouraging grid flexibility and prosumer participation. SCADA (Supervisory Control And Data Acquisition) system data informs cost-efficient energy dispatch strategies, ensuring the most economical generation technologies support the grid. Diagnostic Analytics Diagnostic analytics delves into the root causes of anomalies or system inefficiencies, answering the critical question of "why it happened." This category is vital for identifying bottlenecks and implementing targeted interventions: Geospatial infrastructure mapping highlights areas with energy access deficits, uncovering the structural and policy constraints impeding progress. Land use and demographic data guide off-grid renewable energy installations, ensuring equitable and efficient energy access expansion.
Stage 4: Utilization

This stage focus on how the analyzed data are presented to the end user for decision-making purposes. There are two main sub-processes involved; data visualization and data dissemination, both of which unpack how the user or system interacts with the data in a meaningful way. Tools such as the Energy access explorer , global electrification platform , energy data platform, and clean energy access tool showcase the impactful potential of data driven dashboards in informing strategies and accelerating sustainable energy development initiatives. Data presentation and visualization are key to effectively communicating the insights derived from the analysis, which can then be used to inform decision making. This process facilitates the translation of complex robust data into a clear and comprehensible format, enabling interaction from different types of stakeholders, policymakers, country office representatives, and researchers. content.title: Part 2: Overcoming Challenges in Developing Countries

content.text: Part 2 Overview

The data value chain holds immense potential to accelerate sustainable energy development in developing countries, but systemic barriers often prevent its effective use. These challenges—rooted in infrastructure gaps, socio-cultural complexities, and governance weaknesses—demand holistic strategies to unlock data’s transformative power while ensuring equity. Next, we will explore these hurdles and pathways to address them.

Developing countries face multifaceted obstacles across the data lifecycle, from collection to application. Fragmented systems, technical limitations, as well as social and economic inequities compound these challenges, risking exclusionary outcomes.
Key Challenges in the Data Value Chain
Data Fragmentation and Accessibility

Critical energy datasets are often siloed across ministries, NGOs, and private actors, with inconsistent formats or languages. For example, rural electrification data in local languages may remain untranslated, hindering global collaboration.
Technical Limitations

Low-cost sensors, though affordable, frequently produce unreliable data. Compatibility issues between devices exacerbate interoperability challenges, especially when merging datasets from diverse sources.
Human and Institutional Gaps
Limited technical expertise and weak governance frameworks stifle the ability to process, analyze, and act on data insights.

The energy data value chain—from collection to application—is deeply intertwined with socio-cultural dynamics and systemic inequities in developing countries. Ignoring these dimensions risks perpetuating exclusion, eroding trust, and designing policies that fail to address the needs of marginalized groups. Below, we examine key challenges and their implications for equitable energy transitions.
Socio-Cultural and Equity Considerations
Cultural Identity and Resource Access

Energy data collection often overlooks cultural ties to land and resources. For example, in Colombia, where indigenous and Afro-Colombian communities collectively manage 33% of the territory, deforestation data used for climate goals rarely incorporates their traditional knowledge. This exclusion skews energy transition models, prioritizing carbon metrics over cultural preservation and livelihoods tied to forests.
Language and Representation Barriers

Energy datasets in countries like India or Nigeria are often published in colonial languages (e.g., English), excluding populations who speak only local languages. This limits community engagement in validating data accuracy or participating in demand-side management programs.
Gender Disparities in Energy Data

Household energy surveys in rural areas frequently default to male heads of households as respondents, underrepresenting women’s experiences with energy poverty or clean cooking needs. This bias in data design perpetuates gender-blind policies, limiting the impact of programs like solar home systems or biogas initiatives.

content.title: A. UNDP Data Governance Framework for Türkiye

content.text: Key Components of the Framework
The framework, developed through multi-stakeholder consultations with public institutions, private sector actors, academia, and NGOs, is structured around five pillars
Policies, Legislation, and Regulations
Aligning Türkiye’s data practices with international standards (e.g., GDPR) to ensure ethical data sharing and compliance.
Institutions, Mechanisms, and Processes
Establishing clear roles for data stewardship and creating interoperable systems to break down silos.
People
Building technical capacity for data management and fostering a culture of transparency, including training for government and civil society.
Technology and Infrastructure
Prioritizing tools like data catalogs, APIs, and cloud solutions to enable secure, scalable data flows.
Partnerships
Encouraging cross-sector collaboration to address shared challenges, such as integrating energy access data with climate adaptation strategies.

A cornerstone of the framework is its emphasis on Digital Public Infrastructure (DPI), which underpins energy data systems through interoperable platforms for real-time monitoring, analysis, and decision support
Sensor and Interoperability Gaps
The focus on technology infrastructure promotes investment in high-quality sensors and compatible systems, mitigating errors from low-cost devices—a common issue in off-grid energy projects.
Capacity Shortfalls
Training programs under the “People” pillar empower local stakeholders to analyze energy data, such as solar potential maps or demand patterns, ensuring communities co-design solutions
Equity and Inclusion

The framework’s people-centric ethos ensures marginalized groups (e.g., rural households, women-led cooperatives) contribute to and benefit from energy data, aligning with UNDP’s broader goals of inclusive digital transformation

Türkiye’s alignment with the framework could enhance its ability to manage renewable energy transitions by linking grid expansion data with socio-economic indicators, ensuring no community is left behind—a model applicable to other developing nations grappling with similar energy equity challenges.

content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: The data value chain is essential for transforming raw data into actionable insights for sustainable energy development.
takeaways.description: From collection to utilization, the data value chain optimizes energy systems, improves grid management, and supports decentralized solutions, enabling informed decision-making for sustainable energy transitions.

takeaways.title: Advanced data analytics unlock the potential of energy data.
takeaways.description: Descriptive, predictive, prescriptive, and diagnostic analytics help interpret trends, forecast scenarios, optimize systems, and identify inefficiencies, empowering evidence-based energy strategies.

takeaways.title: Developing countries face challenges in leveraging data for energy.
takeaways.description: Limited infrastructure, poor sensors, and unstable connectivity hinder data use. Investments in quality sensors, connectivity, and capacity-building are essential to overcome these barriers
